verses.text: Then the people of the land took Jehoahaz the son of Josiah and made him king in Jerusalem in place of his father.
verses.comment: Follows the Hebrew text closely.

verses.text: Jehoahaz was twenty-three years old when he began to reign, and he reigned three months in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Age and duration of reign consistent with source.

verses.text: Then the king of Egypt removed him from Jerusalem and imposed on the land a tribute of one hundred talents of silver and a talent of gold.
verses.comment: Egyptian tribute preserved.

verses.text: The king of Egypt made Eliakim, Jehoahaz’s brother, king over Judah and Jerusalem, and changed his name to Jehoiakim. But he took Jehoahaz away to Egypt.
verses.comment: Name change and exile as in original.

verses.text: Jehoiakim was twenty-five years old when he began to reign, and he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem. He did what was evil in the sight of the LORD his God.
verses.comment: Age and evil works specified; phrase matches Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon came up against him and bound him in bronze chains to take him to Babylon.
verses.comment: Instrument ('bronze chains') clarified for accuracy.

verses.text: Nebuchadnezzar also carried off some of the vessels of the house of the LORD to Babylon and put them in his palace there.
verses.comment: Palace = 'temple;' kept for clarity as in text.

verses.text: Now the rest of the deeds of Jehoiakim, and his detestable acts which he did, and what was found against him, are written in the Book of the Kings of Israel and Judah. And Jehoiachin his son reigned in his place.
verses.comment: ‘Detestable acts’ renders ‘abominations’ for readability.

verses.text: Jehoiachin was eighteen years old when he became king, and he reigned three months and ten days in Jerusalem. He did what was evil in the sight of the LORD.
verses.comment: Some manuscripts say ‘eight’ instead of ‘eighteen’—‘eighteen’ used for majority tradition.

verses.text: At the turn of the year, King Nebuchadnezzar sent and brought him to Babylon, along with vessels of value from the house of the LORD, and made Zedekiah, his relative, king over Judah and Jerusalem.
verses.comment: ‘Turn of the year’ = spring time; ‘relative’ renders ‘brother’ for clarity.

verses.text: Zedekiah was twenty-one years old when he became king, and he reigned eleven years in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: Age and reign duration preserved.

verses.text: He did what was evil in the sight of the LORD his God; he did not humble himself before Jeremiah the prophet who spoke from the mouth of the LORD.
verses.comment: Phrase ‘from the mouth of the LORD’ kept for literal accuracy.

verses.text: He also rebelled against King Nebuchadnezzar, who had made him swear by God, but he stiffened his neck and hardened his heart against turning to the LORD God of Israel.
verses.comment: ‘Stiffened his neck and hardened his heart’ matches original idiom.

verses.text: Also, all the leaders of the priests and the people increased in their faithlessness, following all the abominations of the nations, and they defiled the house of the LORD which he had consecrated in Jerusalem.
verses.comment: ‘Abominations’ kept for theological accuracy.

verses.text: The LORD, the God of their fathers, sent word to them persistently by his messengers, because he had compassion on his people and on his dwelling place.
verses.comment: ‘Sent word persistently’ translates ‘rising early and sending’ phrase.

verses.text: But they kept mocking the messengers of God, despising his words and scoffing at his prophets, until the wrath of the LORD rose against his people, until there was no remedy.
verses.comment: ‘No remedy’ matches Hebrew phrase meaning ‘no healing.’

verses.text: So he brought up against them the king of the Chaldeans, who killed their young men with the sword in the house of their sanctuary, and had no compassion on young man or virgin, old man or aged. He gave them all into his hand.
verses.comment: ‘Chaldeans’ is an alternate term for Babylonians.

verses.text: And all the vessels of the house of God, great and small, and the treasures of the house of the LORD and the treasures of the king and his officials, all these he brought to Babylon.
verses.comment: All items specified for literal completion.

verses.text: And they burned the house of God and broke down the wall of Jerusalem, and burned all its palaces with fire, and destroyed all its precious objects.
verses.comment: Destruction order kept consistent with original sources.

verses.text: He took into exile in Babylon those who had escaped from the sword, and they became servants to him and to his sons until the kingdom of Persia came to power.
verses.comment: Exile and servitude conclusion rendered plainly.

verses.text: To fulfill the word of the LORD by the mouth of Jeremiah, until the land had enjoyed its Sabbaths; all the days of its desolation it kept Sabbath, to fulfill seventy years.
verses.comment: ‘Kept Sabbath’ matches phrase about land resting per prophecy.

verses.text: Now in the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, to fulfill the word of the LORD spoken by Jeremiah, the LORD stirred up the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia so that he made a proclamation throughout all his kingdom and put it in writing:
verses.comment: ‘Stirred up the spirit’ is a Hebrew idiom, kept literal.

verses.text: "Thus says Cyrus king of Persia: ‘The LORD, the God of heaven, has given me all the kingdoms of the earth, and he has appointed me to build a house for him in Jerusalem, which is in Judah. Whoever among you is of his people—may the LORD his God be with him. Let him go up.’"
verses.comment: Cyrus’s proclamation rendered as direct quotation.
